Algorithmically Effective Differentially Private Synthetic Data

Yiyun He Department of Mathematics, University of California Irvine, Irvine, CA 92697 yiyunh4@uci.edu ,  Roman Vershynin Department of Mathematics, University of California Irvine, Irvine, CA 92697 rvershyn@uci.edu  and  Yizhe Zhu Department of Mathematics, University of California Irvine, Irvine, CA 92697 yizhe.zhu@uci.edu
Abstract.

We present a highly effective algorithmic approach for generating ε𝜀\varepsilon-differentially private synthetic data in a bounded metric space with near-optimal utility guarantees under the 1-Wasserstein distance. In particular, for a dataset 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} in the hypercube [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d}, our algorithm generates synthetic dataset 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} such that the expected 1-Wasserstein distance between the empirical measure of 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} is O​((ε​n)−1/d)𝑂superscript𝜀𝑛1𝑑O((\varepsilon n)^{-1/d}) for d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2, and is O​(log2⁡(ε​n)​(ε​n)−1)𝑂superscript2𝜀𝑛superscript𝜀𝑛1O(\log^{2}(\varepsilon n)(\varepsilon n)^{-1}) for d=1𝑑1d=1. The accuracy guarantee is optimal up to a constant factor for d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2, and up to a logarithmic factor for d=1𝑑1d=1. Our algorithm has a fast running time of O​(ε​d​n)𝑂𝜀𝑑𝑛O(\varepsilon dn) for all d≥1𝑑1d\geq 1 and demonstrates improved accuracy compared to the method in [12] for d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2.

1. Introduction

Differential privacy has become the benchmark for privacy protection in scenarios where vast amounts of data need to be analyzed. The aim of differential privacy is to prevent the disclosure of information about individual participants in the dataset. In simple terms, an algorithm that has a randomized output and produces similar results when given two adjacent datasets is considered to be differentially private. This method of privacy protection is increasingly being adopted and implemented in various fields, including the 2020 US Census [2, 29, 28] and numerous machine learning tasks [24].

A wide range of data computations can be performed in a differentially private manner, including regression [17], clustering [37], parameter estimation [21], stochastic gradient descent [36], and deep learning [1]. However, many existing works on differential privacy focus on designing algorithms for specific tasks and are restricted to queries that are predefined before use. This requires expert knowledge and often involves modifying existing algorithms.

One promising solution to this challenge is to generate a synthetic dataset similar to the original dataset with guaranteed differential privacy [27, 8, 31, 7, 10, 11, 12]. As any downstream tasks are based on the synthetic dataset, they can be performed without incurring additional privacy costs.

1.1. Private synthetic data

Mathematically, the problem of generating private synthetic data can be defined as follows. Let (Ω,ρ)Ω𝜌(\Omega,\rho) be a metric space. Consider a dataset 𝒳=(X1,…,Xn)∈Ωn𝒳subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛superscriptΩ𝑛\mathcal{X}=(X_{1},\dots,X_{n})\in\Omega^{n}. Our goal is to construct an efficient randomized algorithm that outputs differentially private synthetic data 𝒴=(Y1,…,Ym)∈Ωm𝒴subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑚superscriptΩ𝑚\mathcal{Y}=(Y_{1},\dots,Y_{m})\in\Omega^{m} such that the two empirical measures

μ𝒳=1n​∑i=1nδXiandμ𝒴=1m​∑i=1mδYiformulae-sequencesubscript𝜇𝒳1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝛿subscript𝑋𝑖andsubscript𝜇𝒴1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛿subscript𝑌𝑖\mu_{\mathcal{X}}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\delta_{X_{i}}\quad\text{and}\quad\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\delta_{Y_{i}}

are close to each other. We measure the utility of the output by 𝔼⁡W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒴)𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇𝒴\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}), where W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒴)subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇𝒴W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}) is the 1-Wasserstein distance, and the expectation is taken over the randomness of the algorithm. The Kantorovich-Rubinstein duality (see, e.g., [47]) gives an equivalent representation of the 1-Wasserstein distance between two measures ν𝒳subscript𝜈𝒳\nu_{\mathcal{X}} and μ𝒴subscript𝜇𝒴\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}:

W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒴)=supLip​(f)≤1(∫f​dμ𝒳−∫f​dμ𝒴),subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇𝒴subscriptsupremumLip𝑓1𝑓differential-dsubscript𝜇𝒳𝑓differential-dsubscript𝜇𝒴W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}})=\sup_{{\mathrm{Lip}(f)}\leq 1}\left(\int f\mathrm{d}\mu_{\mathcal{X}}-\int f\mathrm{d}\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}\right), (1.1)

where the supremum is taken over the set of all 111-Lipschitz functions on ΩΩ\Omega. Since many machine learning algorithms are Lipschitz [48, 32, 15, 35], Equation (1.1) provides a uniform accuracy guarantee for a wide range of machine learning tasks performed on synthetic datasets whose empirical measure is close to μ𝒳subscript𝜇𝒳\mu_{\mathcal{X}} in the 1-Wasserstein distance.

1.2. Main results

The most straightforward way to construct differentially private synthetic data is to add independent noise to the location of each data point. However, this method can result in a significant loss of data utility as the amount of noise needed for privacy protection may be too large [20]. Another direct approach could be to add noise to the density function of the empirical measure of 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, by dividing ΩΩ\Omega into small subregions and perturbing the true counts in each subregion. However, Laplacian noise may perturb the count in a certain subregion to negative, causing the output to become a signed measure. To address this issue, we introduce an algorithmically effective method called the Private Measure Mechanism.

Private Measure Mechanism (PMM)

PMM makes the count zero if the noisy count in a subregion is negative. Instead of a single partition of ΩΩ\Omega, we consider a collection of binary hierarchical partitions on ΩΩ\Omega and add inhomogeneous noise to each level of the partition. However, the counts of two subregions do not always add up to the count of the region at a higher level. We develop an algorithm that enforces the consistency of counts in regions at different levels. PMM has O​(ε​d​n)𝑂𝜀𝑑𝑛O(\varepsilon dn) running time while the running time of the approach in [12] is polynomial in n𝑛n.

The accuracy analysis of PMM uses the hierarchical partitions to estimate the 1-Wasserstein distance in terms of the multi-scale geometry of ΩΩ\Omega and the noise magnitude in each level of the partition. In particular, when Ω=[0,1]dΩsuperscript01𝑑\Omega=[0,1]^{d}, by optimizing the choice of the hierarchical partitions and noise magnitude, PMM achieves better accuracy compared to [12] for d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2. The accuracy is optimal rate up to a constant factor for d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2, and up to a logarithmic factor for d=1𝑑1d=1. We state it in the next theorem.

The hierarchical partitions appeared in many previous works on the approximation of distributions under Wasserstein distances in a non-private setting, including [4, 18, 50]. In the differential privacy literature, the hierarchical partitions are also closely related to the binary tree mechanism [22, 16] for differential privacy under continual observation. However, the accuracy analysis of the two mechanisms is significantly different. In addition, the TopDown algorithm in the 2020 census [3] also has a similar hierarchical structure and enforces consistency, but the accuracy analysis of the algorithm is not provided in [3].

Theorem 1.1 (PMM for data in a hypercube).

Let Ω=[0,1]dΩsuperscript01𝑑\Omega=[0,1]^{d} equipped with the ℓ∞superscriptℓ\ell^{\infty} metric. PMM outputs an ε𝜀\varepsilon-differentially private synthetic dataset 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} in time O​(ε​d​n)𝑂𝜀𝑑𝑛O(\varepsilon dn) such that

𝔼W1(μ𝒳,μ𝒴)≤{C​log2⁡(ε​n)​(ε​n)−1 if ​d=1,C​(ε​n)−1d if ​d≥2.\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}})\leq\left\{\begin{aligned} &C\log^{2}(\varepsilon n)(\varepsilon n)^{-1}&\quad\textrm{ if }d=1,\\ &C{(\varepsilon n)^{-\frac{1}{d}}}&\quad\textrm{ if }d\geq 2.\end{aligned}\right.

Private Signed Measure Mechanism (PSMM)

In addition to PMM, we introduce an alternative method, the Private Signed Measure Mechanism, that achieves optimal accuracy rate on [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d} when d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3 in poly​(n)poly𝑛\text{poly}(n) time. The analysis of PSMM is not restricted to 1-Wasserstein distance, and it can be generalized to provide a uniform utility guarantee of other function classes.

We first partition the domain ΩΩ\Omega into m𝑚m subregions Ω1,…,ΩmsubscriptΩ1…subscriptΩ𝑚\Omega_{1},\dots,\Omega_{m}. Perturbing the counts in each subregion with i.i.d. integer Laplacian noise gives an unbiased approximation of μ𝒴subscript𝜇𝒴\mu_{\mathcal{Y}} with a signed measure ν𝜈\nu. Then we find the closest probability measure ν^^𝜈\hat{\nu} under the bounded Lipschitz distance by solving a linear programming problem.

In the proof of accuracy for PSMM, one ingredient is to estimate the Laplacian complexity of the Lipschitz function class on ΩΩ\Omega and connect it to the 1-Wasserstein distance. This type of argument is similar in spirit to the optimal matching problem for two sets of random points in a metric space [38, 39, 9]. When Ω=[0,1]dΩsuperscript01𝑑\Omega=[0,1]^{d}, PSMM achieves the optimal accuracy rate O​((ε​n)−1/d)𝑂superscript𝜀𝑛1𝑑O((\varepsilon n)^{-1/d}) for d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3. For d=2𝑑2d=2, PSMM achieves a near-optimal accuracy O​(log⁡(ε​n)​(ε​n)−1/2)𝑂𝜀𝑛superscript𝜀𝑛12O(\log(\varepsilon n)(\varepsilon n)^{-1/2}). For d=1𝑑1d=1, the accuracy becomes O​((ε​n)−1/2)𝑂superscript𝜀𝑛12O((\varepsilon n)^{-1/2}).

For the case when d=2𝑑2d=2, we believe that the bound in Corollary 3.7 could be improved to C​log⁡(ε​n)/ε​n𝐶𝜀𝑛𝜀𝑛C\sqrt{\log(\varepsilon n)}/\sqrt{\varepsilon n} by replacing Dudley’s chaining bound in Proposition 3.2 with the generic chaining bound in [39, 19] involving the γ1subscript𝛾1\gamma_{1} and γ2subscript𝛾2\gamma_{2} functionals on ΩΩ\Omega. We will not pursue this direction in this paper.

Comparison to previous results

[42] proved that it is NP-hard to generate private synthetic data on the Boolean cube which approximately preserves all two-dimensional marginals, assuming the existence of one-way functions. There exists a substantial body of work for differentially private synthetic data with guarantees limited to accuracy bounds for a finite set of specified queries [5, 40, 23, 43, 33, 46, 12, 13, 14].

[49] considered differentially private synthetic data in [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d} with guarantees for any smooth queries with bounded partial derivatives of order K𝐾K, and achieved an accuracy of O​(ε−1​n−K2​d+K)𝑂superscript𝜀1superscript𝑛𝐾2𝑑𝐾O(\varepsilon^{-1}n^{-\frac{K}{2d+K}}). Recently, [12] introduced a method based on superregular random walks to generate differentially private synthetic data with near-optimal guarantees in general compact metric spaces. In particular, when the dataset is in [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d}, they obtain 𝔼⁡W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒴)≤C​log32​d⁡(ε​n)​(ε​n)−1d𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇𝒴𝐶superscript32𝑑𝜀𝑛superscript𝜀𝑛1𝑑\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}})\leq C\log^{\frac{3}{2d}}(\varepsilon n)(\varepsilon n)^{-\frac{1}{d}}. A corresponding lower bound of order n−1/dsuperscript𝑛1𝑑n^{-1/d} was also proved in [12, Corollary 9.3]. PMM matches the lower bound up to a constant factor for d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2, and up to a logarithmic factor for d=1𝑑1d=1.

In terms of computational efficiency, PMM runs in time O​(ε​d​n)𝑂𝜀𝑑𝑛O(\varepsilon dn). This is more efficient compared to the algorithm in [12].

Organization of the paper

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we introduce some background on differential privacy and distances between measures. We will first introduce and analyze the easier and more direct method PSMM before our main result. In Section 3, we describe PSMM in detail and prove its privacy and accuracy for data in a bounded metric space, and detailed results are provided for the case for the hypercube. In Section 4, we introduce PMM and analyze its privacy and accuracy. Optimizing the choices of noise parameters, we obtain the optimal accuracy on the hypercube with O​(ε​d​n)𝑂𝜀𝑑𝑛O(\varepsilon dn) running time, which proves Theorem 1.1.

Additional proofs are included in Appendix A. We use a variant of Laplacian distribution, called discrete Laplacian distribution, in PMM and PSMM. The definition and properties of discrete Laplacian distribution are included in Appendix B.

2. Preliminaries

Differential Privacy

We use the following definition from [24]. A randomized algorithm ℳℳ\mathcal{M} provides ε𝜀\varepsilon-differential privacy if for any input data D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime} that differs on only one element (or D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} are adjacent data sets) and for any measurable set S⊆range​(ℳ)𝑆rangeℳS\subseteq\mathrm{range}(\mathcal{M}), there is

ℙ​{ℳ​(D)∈S​}ℙ​{ℳ​(D′)∈S​}≤eε.ℙℳ𝐷𝑆ℙℳsuperscript𝐷′𝑆superscript𝑒𝜀\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{M}(D)\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})\in S\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}\leq e^{\varepsilon}.

Here the probability is taken from the probability space of the randomness of ℳℳ\mathcal{M}.

Wasserstein distance

Consider a metric space (Ω,ρ)Ω𝜌(\Omega,\rho) with two probability measures μ,ν𝜇𝜈\mu,\nu. Then the 1-Wasserstein distance (see e.g., [47] for more details) between them is defined as

W1(μ,ν):=infγ∈Γ​(μ,ν)∫Ω×Ωρ(x,y)dγ(x,y),W_{1}(\mu,\nu)\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\inf_{\gamma\in\Gamma(\mu,\nu)}\int_{\Omega\times\Omega}\rho(x,y)\mathrm{d}\gamma(x,y),

where γ​(μ,ν)𝛾𝜇𝜈\gamma(\mu,\nu) is the set of all couplings of μ𝜇\mu and ν𝜈\nu.

Bounded Lipschitz distance

Let (Ω,ρ)Ω𝜌(\Omega,\rho) be a bounded metric space. The Lipschitz norm of a function f𝑓f is defined as

∥f∥Lip:=max{Lip(f),∥f∥∞diam⁡(Ω)},\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{Lip}}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\max\left\{\mathrm{Lip}(f),\;\frac{\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f\right\rVert}_{\infty}}{\operatorname{diam}(\Omega)}\right\},

where Lip​(f)Lip𝑓\mathrm{Lip}(f) is the Lipschitz constant of f𝑓f. Let ℱℱ\mathcal{F} be the set of all Lipschitz functions f𝑓f on ΩΩ\Omega with ∥f∥Lip≤1subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓Lip1\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{Lip}}\leq 1. For signed measures μ,ν𝜇𝜈\mu,\nu, we define the bounded Lipschitz distance:

dBL(μ,ν):=supf∈ℱ(∫fdμ−∫fdν).d_{\mathrm{BL}}(\mu,\nu)\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}}\left(\int f\mathrm{d}\mu-\int f\mathrm{d}\nu\right).

One can easily check that this is a metric. Moreover, in the special case where μ𝜇\mu and ν𝜈\nu are both probability measures, moving f𝑓f by a constant does not change the result of ∫f​dμ−∫f​dν𝑓differential-d𝜇𝑓differential-d𝜈\int f\mathrm{d}\mu-\int f\mathrm{d}\nu. Therefore, for a bounded domain ΩΩ\Omega, we can always assume f​(x0)=0𝑓subscript𝑥00f(x_{0})=0 for a fixed x0∈Ωsubscript𝑥0Ωx_{0}\in\Omega, then ∥f∥∞≤diam⁡(Ω)subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓diamΩ\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq\operatorname{diam}(\Omega) when computing the supremum in (1.1). This implies dBLsubscript𝑑BLd_{\mathrm{BL}}-metric is equivalent to the classical W1subscript𝑊1W_{1}-metric when μ,ν𝜇𝜈\mu,\nu are both probability measures on a bounded domain ΩΩ\Omega:

W1​(μ,ν)subscript𝑊1𝜇𝜈\displaystyle W_{1}(\mu,\nu) =supLip​(f)≤1(∫f​dμ−∫f​dν)=supf∈ℱ(∫f​dμ−∫f​dν)=dBL​(μ,ν).absentsubscriptsupremumLip𝑓1𝑓differential-d𝜇𝑓differential-d𝜈subscriptsupremum𝑓ℱ𝑓differential-d𝜇𝑓differential-d𝜈subscript𝑑BL𝜇𝜈\displaystyle=\sup_{{\mathrm{Lip}(f)\leq 1}}\left(\int f\mathrm{d}\mu-\int f\mathrm{d}\nu\right)=\sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}}\left(\int f\mathrm{d}\mu-\int f\mathrm{d}\nu\right)=d_{\mathrm{BL}}(\mu,\nu). (2.1)

3. Private signed measure mechanism (PSMM)

We will first introduce PSMM, which is an easier and more intuitive approach. The procedure of PSMM is formally described in Algorithm 1. Note that in the output step of Algorithm 1, the size of the synthetic data m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime} depends on the rational approximation of the density function of ν^^𝜈\hat{\nu}, and we discuss the details here. Let v^1,…,v^msubscript^𝑣1…subscript^𝑣𝑚\hat{v}_{1},\dots,\hat{v}_{m} be the weight of the probability measure ν^^𝜈\hat{\nu} on y1,…,ymsubscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑚y_{1},\dots,y_{m}, respectively. We can choose rational numbers r1,…,rmsubscript𝑟1…subscript𝑟𝑚r_{1},\dots,r_{m} such that maxi∈[m]⁡|ri−ν^i|subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚subscript𝑟𝑖subscript^𝜈𝑖\max_{i\in[m]}|r_{i}-\hat{\nu}_{i}| is arbitrarily small. Let m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime} be the least common multiple of the denominators of r1,…,rmsubscript𝑟1…subscript𝑟𝑚r_{1},\dots,r_{m}, then we output the synthetic dataset 𝒴^^𝒴\hat{\mathcal{Y}} containing m′​risuperscript𝑚′subscript𝑟𝑖m^{\prime}r_{i} copies of yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} for i=1,…,m𝑖1…𝑚i=1,\dots,m.

Before analyzing the privacy and accuracy of PSMM, we introduce a useful complexity measure of a given function class, which quantifies the influence of the Laplacian noise on the function class.

3.1. Laplacian complexity

Given the Kantorovich-Rubinstein duality (1.1), to control the W1subscript𝑊1W_{1}-distance between the original measure and the private measure, we need to describe how Lipschitz functions behave under Laplacian noise. As an analog of the worst-case Rademacher complexity [6, 25], we consider the worst-case Laplacian complexity. Such a worst-case complexity measure appears since the original dataset is deterministic without any distribution assumption.

Definition 3.1 (Worst-case Laplacian complexity).

Let ℱℱ\mathcal{F} be a function class on a metric space ΩΩ\Omega. The worst-case Laplacian complexity of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is defined by

Ln(ℱ):=supX1,…,Xn∈Ω𝔼[supf∈ℱ|1n∑i=1nλif(Xi)|],\displaystyle L_{n}(\mathcal{F})\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\sup_{X_{1},\dots,X_{n}\in\Omega}\mathbb{E}\left[\sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}}\left|\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\lambda_{i}f(X_{i})\right|\right], (3.1)

where λ1,…,λn∼Lap⁡(1)similar-tosubscript𝜆1…subscript𝜆𝑛Lap1\lambda_{1},\dots,\lambda_{n}\sim\operatorname{Lap}(1) are i.i.d. random variables.

Since Laplacian random variables are sub-exponential but not sub-gaussian, its complexity measure is not equivalent to the Gaussian or Rademacher complexity, but it is related to the suprema of the mixed tail process [19] and the quadratic empirical process [34]. Our next proposition bounds Ln​(ℱ)subscript𝐿𝑛ℱL_{n}(\mathcal{F}) in terms of the covering numbers of ℱℱ\mathcal{F}. Its proof is a classical application of Dudley’s chaining method (see, e.g., [45]).

Proposition 3.2 (Bounding Laplacian complexity with Dudley’s entropy integral).

Suppose that (Ω,ρ)Ω𝜌(\Omega,\rho) is a metric space and ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is a set of functions on ΩΩ\Omega. Then

Ln(ℱ)≤Cinfα>0(2α+1n∫α∞log𝒩(ℱ,u,∥⋅∥∞)du+1n∫α∞log𝒩(ℱ,u,∥⋅∥∞)du)L_{n}(\mathcal{F})\leq C\inf_{\alpha>0}\left(2\alpha+\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\int_{\alpha}^{\infty}\sqrt{{\log\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{F},u,\|\cdot\|_{\infty})}}\mathrm{d}u+\frac{1}{{n}}\int_{\alpha}^{\infty}{\log\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{F},u,\|\cdot\|_{\infty})}\mathrm{d}u\right)

where 𝒩(ℱ,u,∥⋅∥∞)\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{F},u,\|\cdot\|_{\infty}) is the covering number of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} and C>0𝐶0C>0 is an absolute constant.

In particular, we are interested in the case where ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is the class of all the bounded Lipschitz functions. One can find the result in [41] or more explicit bound in [26] that for the set ℱℱ\mathcal{F} of functions f𝑓f with ∥f∥Lip≤1subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓Lip1\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{Lip}}\leq 1, its covering number satisfies

𝒩(ℱ,u,∥⋅∥∞)≤(8u)𝒩​(Ω,u/2,ρ).\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{F},u,\|\cdot\|_{\infty})\leq\left(\frac{8}{u}\right)^{\mathcal{N}(\Omega,{u}/{2},\rho)}.

When Ω=[0,1]dΩsuperscript01𝑑\Omega=[0,1]^{d}, a better bound on the covering number for Lipschitz functions is available from [41, 48]:

𝒩(ℱ,u,∥⋅∥∞)≤(2⌈2/u⌉+1)2𝒩([0,1]d,u/2,∥⋅∥∞),\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{F},u,\|\cdot\|_{\infty})\leq\left(2\left\lceil{2}/u\right\rceil+1\right)2^{\mathcal{N}\left([0,1]^{d},u/2,\|\cdot\|_{\infty}\right)},

which implies the following corollary.

Corollary 3.3 (Laplacian complexity for Lipschitz functions on the hypercube).

Let Ω=[0,1]dΩsuperscript01𝑑\Omega=[0,1]^{d} with the ∥⋅∥∞\|\cdot\|_{\infty} metric, and ℱℱ\mathcal{F} be the set of all Lipschitz functions f𝑓f on ΩΩ\Omega with ∥f∥Lip≤1subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓Lip1\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f\right\rVert}_{\mathrm{Lip}}\leq 1. We have

Ln(ℱ)≤{C​n−1/2 if ​d=1,C​log⁡n⋅n−1/2 if ​d=2,C​d−1​n−1/d if ​d≥3.L_{n}(\mathcal{F})\leq\left\{\begin{aligned} &Cn^{-1/2}\quad&\textrm{ if }d=1,\\ &{C\log n}\cdot n^{-1/2}\quad&\textrm{ if }d=2,\\ &Cd^{-1}{n^{-{1}/{d}}}\quad&\textrm{ if }d\geq 3.\end{aligned}\right.

Discrete Laplacian complexity

Laplacian complexity can be useful for differential privacy algorithms based on the Laplacian mechanism [24]. However, since PSMM perturbs counts in each subregion, it is more convenient for us to add integer noise to the true counts. Instead, we will use the worst-case discrete Laplacian complexity defined below:

L~n(ℱ):=supX1,…,Xn∈Ω𝔼[supf∈ℱ|1n∑i=1nλif(Xi)|],\displaystyle\widetilde{L}_{n}(\mathcal{F})\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\sup_{X_{1},\dots,X_{n}\in\Omega}\mathbb{E}\left[\sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}}\left|\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\lambda_{i}f(X_{i})\right|\right], (3.2)

where λ1,…,λn∼Lapℤ⁡(1)similar-tosubscript𝜆1…subscript𝜆𝑛subscriptLapℤ1\lambda_{1},\dots,\lambda_{n}\sim\operatorname{Lap}_{\mathbb{Z}}(1) are i.i.d. discrete Laplacian random variables.

In particular, Lapℤ⁡(1)subscriptLapℤ1\operatorname{Lap}_{\mathbb{Z}}(1) has a bounded sub-exponential norm, therefore the proof of Proposition 3.2 works for discrete Laplacian random variables as well. Consequently, Corollary 3.3 also holds for L~n​(ℱ)subscript~𝐿𝑛ℱ\widetilde{L}_{n}(\mathcal{F}), with a different absolute constant C𝐶C.

3.2. Privacy and Accuracy of Algorithm 1

The privacy guarantee of Algorithm 1 can be proved by checking the definition. The essence of the proof is the same as the classical Laplacian mechanism [24].

Proposition 3.4 (Privacy of Algorithm 1).

Algorithm 1 is ε𝜀\varepsilon-differentially private.

We now turn to accuracy. The linear programming problem stated in Algorithm 2 has (2​m2+2​m)2superscript𝑚22𝑚(2m^{2}+2m) many variables and (m+1)𝑚1(m+1) many constraints, which can be solved in polynomial time in m𝑚m. We first show that Algorithm 2 indeed outputs the closest probability measure to ν𝜈\nu in the dBLsubscript𝑑BLd_{\mathrm{BL}}-distance in the next proposition.

Proposition 3.5.

For a discrete signed measure ν𝜈\nu on ΩΩ\Omega, Algorithm 2 gives its closest probability measure in dBLsubscript𝑑BLd_{\mathrm{BL}}-distance with the same support set with a polynomial running time in m𝑚m.

Now we are ready to analyze the accuracy of Algorithm 1. In PSMM, independent Laplacian noise is added to the count of each sub-region. Therefore, the Laplacian complexity arises when considering the expected Wasserstein distance between the original empirical measure and the synthetic measure.

Theorem 3.6 (Accuracy of Algorithm 1).

Suppose (Ω1,…,Ωm)subscriptΩ1…subscriptΩ𝑚(\Omega_{1},\dots,\Omega_{m}) is a partition of (Ω,ρ)Ω𝜌(\Omega,\rho) and ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is the set of all functions with Lipschitz norm bounded by 111. Then the measure ν^^𝜈\hat{\nu} generated from Algorithm 1 satisfies

𝔼⁡W1​(μ𝒳,ν^)≤maxi⁡diam⁡(Ωi)+2​mε​n​L~m​(ℱ).𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳^𝜈subscript𝑖diamsubscriptΩ𝑖2𝑚𝜀𝑛subscript~𝐿𝑚ℱ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\hat{\nu})\leq\max_{i}\operatorname{diam}(\Omega_{i})+\frac{2m}{\varepsilon n}\widetilde{L}_{m}(\mathcal{F}).

Note that diam⁡(Ωi)≍m−1/dasymptotically-equalsdiamsubscriptΩ𝑖superscript𝑚1𝑑\operatorname{diam}(\Omega_{i})\asymp m^{-1/d} can be satisfied when we take a partition of Ω=[0,1]dΩsuperscript01𝑑\Omega=[0,1]^{d} where each ΩisubscriptΩ𝑖\Omega_{i} is a subcube of the same size. Using the formula above and the result of Laplacian complexity for the hypercube in Corollary 3.3, one can easily deduce the following result.

Corollary 3.7 (Accuracy of Algorithm 1 on the hypercube).

Take m=⌈ε​n⌉𝑚𝜀𝑛m=\lceil\varepsilon n\rceil and let (Ω1,…,Ωm)subscriptΩ1…subscriptΩ𝑚(\Omega_{1},\dots,\Omega_{m}) be a partition of Ω=[0,1]dΩsuperscript01𝑑\Omega=[0,1]^{d} with the norm ∥⋅∥∞\|\cdot\|_{\infty}. Assume that diam⁡(Ωi)≍m−1/dasymptotically-equalsdiamsubscriptΩ𝑖superscript𝑚1𝑑\operatorname{diam}(\Omega_{i})\asymp m^{-1/d}. Then the measure ν^^𝜈\hat{\nu} generated from Algorithm 1 satisfies

𝔼W1(μ𝒳,ν^)≤{C​(ε​n)−12 if ​d=1,C​log⁡(ε​n)​(ε​n)−12 if ​d=2,C​(ε​n)−1d if ​d≥3.\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\hat{\nu})\leq\left\{\begin{aligned} &C(\varepsilon n)^{-\frac{1}{2}}&\quad\textrm{ if }d=1,\\ &{C}\log(\varepsilon n)(\varepsilon n)^{-\frac{1}{2}}&\quad\textrm{ if }d=2,\\ &C{(\varepsilon n)^{-\frac{1}{d}}}&\quad\textrm{ if }d\geq 3.\end{aligned}\right.

4. Private measure mechanism (PMM)

4.1. Binary partition and noisy counts

A binary hierarchical partition of a set ΩΩ\Omega of depth r𝑟r is a family of subsets ΩθsubscriptΩ𝜃\Omega_{\theta} indexed by θ∈{0,1}≤r𝜃superscript01absent𝑟\theta\in\{0,1\}^{\leq r}, where

{0,1}≤k={0,1}0⊔{0,1}1⊔⋯⊔{0,1}k,k=0,1,2​…,formulae-sequencesuperscript01absent𝑘square-unionsuperscript010superscript011⋯superscript01𝑘𝑘012…\{0,1\}^{\leq k}=\{0,1\}^{0}\sqcup\{0,1\}^{1}\sqcup\cdots\sqcup\{0,1\}^{k},\quad k=0,1,2\dots,

and such that ΩθsubscriptΩ𝜃\Omega_{\theta} is partitioned into Ωθ​0subscriptΩ𝜃0\Omega_{\theta 0} and Ωθ​1subscriptΩ𝜃1\Omega_{\theta 1} for every θ∈{0,1}≤r−1𝜃superscript01absent𝑟1\theta\in\{0,1\}^{\leq r-1}. By convention, the cube {0,1}0superscript010\{0,1\}^{0} consists of a single element ∅\emptyset. We usually drop the subscript ∅\emptyset and write n𝑛n instead of n∅subscript𝑛n_{\emptyset}. When θ∈{0,1}j𝜃superscript01𝑗\theta\in\{0,1\}^{j}, we call j𝑗j the level of θ𝜃\theta. We can also encode a binary hierarchical partition of ΩΩ\Omega in a binary tree of depth r𝑟r, where the root is labeled ΩΩ\Omega and the j𝑗j-th level of the tree encodes the subsets ΩθsubscriptΩ𝜃\Omega_{\theta} for θ𝜃\theta at level j𝑗j.

Let (Ωθ)θ∈{0,1}≤rsubscriptsubscriptΩ𝜃𝜃superscript01absent𝑟(\Omega_{\theta})_{\theta\in\{0,1\}^{\leq r}} be a binary partition of ΩΩ\Omega. Given true data (x1,…,xn)∈Ωnsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛superscriptΩ𝑛(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})\in\Omega^{n}, the true count nθsubscript𝑛𝜃n_{\theta} is the number of data points in the region ΩθsubscriptΩ𝜃\Omega_{\theta}, i.e.

nθ≔|{i∈[n]:xi∈Ωθ}|.≔subscript𝑛𝜃𝑖delimited-[]𝑛:subscript𝑥𝑖subscriptΩ𝜃n_{\theta}\coloneqq\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\left\{i\in[n]\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\;x_{i}\in\Omega_{\theta}\right\}\right\rvert}.

We will convert true counts into noisy counts nθ′subscriptsuperscript𝑛′𝜃n^{\prime}_{\theta} by adding Laplacian noise; all regions on the same level will receive noise of the same expected magnitude. Formally, we set

nθ′≔(nθ+λθ)+,whereλθ∼Lapℤ⁡(σj),formulae-sequence≔subscriptsuperscript𝑛′𝜃subscriptsubscript𝑛𝜃subscript𝜆𝜃wheresimilar-tosubscript𝜆𝜃subscriptLapℤsubscript𝜎𝑗n^{\prime}_{\theta}\coloneqq\left(n_{\theta}+\lambda_{\theta}\right)_{+},\quad\text{where}\quad\lambda_{\theta}\sim\operatorname{Lap}_{\mathbb{Z}}(\sigma_{j}),

and j∈{0,…,r}𝑗0…𝑟j\in\{0,\ldots,r\} is the level of θ𝜃\theta. At this point, the magnitudes of the noise σjsubscript𝜎𝑗\sigma_{j} can be arbitrary.

4.2. Consistency

The true counts nθsubscript𝑛𝜃n_{\theta} are non-negative and consistent, i.e., the counts of subregions always add up to the count of the region:

nθ​0+nθ​1=nθfor all ​θ∈{0,1}≤r−1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑛𝜃0subscript𝑛𝜃1subscript𝑛𝜃for all 𝜃superscript01absent𝑟1n_{\theta 0}+n_{\theta 1}=n_{\theta}\quad\text{for all }\theta\in\{0,1\}^{\leq r-1}.

The noisy counts nθ′subscriptsuperscript𝑛′𝜃n^{\prime}_{\theta} are non-negative, but not necessarily consistent. Algorithm 3 enforces consistency by adjusting the counts iteratively, from top to bottom. In the case of the deficit, when the sum of the two subregional counts is smaller than the count of the region, we increase both subregional counts. In the opposite case or surplus, we decrease both subregional counts. Apart from this requirement, we are free to distribute the deficit or surplus between the subregional counts.

It is convenient to state this requirement by considering a product partial order on ℤ+2superscriptsubscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}, where we declare that (a0,a1)⪯(b0,b1)precedes-or-equalssubscript𝑎0subscript𝑎1subscript𝑏0subscript𝑏1(a_{0},a_{1})\preceq(b_{0},b_{1}) if and only if a0≤b0subscript𝑎0subscript𝑏0a_{0}\leq b_{0} and a1≤b1subscript𝑎1subscript𝑏1a_{1}\leq b_{1}. We call the two vectors a,b∈ℤ2𝑎𝑏superscriptℤ2a,b\in\mathbb{Z}^{2} comparable if either a⪯bprecedes-or-equals𝑎𝑏a\preceq b or b⪯aprecedes-or-equals𝑏𝑎b\preceq a. Furthermore, L​(a)𝐿𝑎L(a) denotes the line x+y=a𝑥𝑦𝑎x+y=a on the plane.

At each step, Algorithm 3 uses a transformation fθ:ℤ+2→ℤ+2∩L​(mθ).:subscript𝑓𝜃superscriptsubscriptℤ2→superscriptsubscriptℤ2𝐿subscript𝑚𝜃f_{\theta}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}\to\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}\cap L(m_{\theta}). It can be chosen arbitrarily; the only requirement is that fθ​(x)subscript𝑓𝜃𝑥f_{\theta}(x) be comparable with x𝑥x. The comparability requirement is natural and non-restrictive. For example, the uniform transformation selects the closest point in the discrete interval ℤ+2∩L​(mθ)superscriptsubscriptℤ2𝐿subscript𝑚𝜃\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}\cap L(m_{\theta}) in (say) the Euclidean metric. Alternatively, the proportional transformation selects the point in the discrete interval ℤ+2∩L​(mθ)superscriptsubscriptℤ2𝐿subscript𝑚𝜃\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}\cap L(m_{\theta}) that is closest to the line that connects the input vector and the origin.

4.3. Synthetic data

Algorithm 3 ensures that the output counts mθsubscript𝑚𝜃m_{\theta} are non-negative, integer, and consistent. They are also private since they are a function of the noisy counts nθ′subscriptsuperscript𝑛′𝜃n^{\prime}_{\theta}, which are private as we proved. Therefore, the counts mθsubscript𝑚𝜃m_{\theta} can be used to generate private synthetic data by putting mθsubscript𝑚𝜃m_{\theta} points in cell ΩθsubscriptΩ𝜃\Omega_{\theta}. Algorithm 4 makes this formal.

4.4. Privacy and accuracy of Algorithm 4

We first prove that Algorithm 4 is differentially private. The proof idea is similar to the classic Laplacian mechanism. But now our noise is of differential scale for each level, so more delicate calculations are needed.

Theorem 4.1 (Privacy of Algorithm 4).

The vector of noisy counts (nθ+λθ)subscript𝑛𝜃subscript𝜆𝜃(n_{\theta}+\lambda_{\theta}) in Algorithm 4 is ε𝜀\varepsilon-differentially private, where

ε=∑j=0r1σj.𝜀superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑟1subscript𝜎𝑗\varepsilon=\sum_{j=0}^{r}\frac{1}{\sigma_{j}}.

Consequently, the synthetic data 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} generated by Algorithm 4 is ε𝜀\varepsilon-differentially private.

Having analyzed the privacy of the synthetic data, we now turn to its accuracy. It is determined by the magnitudes of the noise σjsubscript𝜎𝑗\sigma_{j} and by the multiscale geometry of the domain ΩΩ\Omega. The latter is captured by the diameters of the regions ΩθsubscriptΩ𝜃\Omega_{\theta}, specifically by their sum at each level, which we denote

Δj≔∑θ∈{0,1}jdiam⁡(Ωθ)≔subscriptΔ𝑗subscript𝜃superscript01𝑗diamsubscriptΩ𝜃\Delta_{j}\coloneqq\sum_{\theta\in\{0,1\}^{j}}\operatorname{diam}(\Omega_{\theta}) (4.1)

and adopt the notation Δ−1≔Δ0=diam⁡(Ω).≔subscriptΔ1subscriptΔ0diamΩ\Delta_{-1}\coloneqq\Delta_{0}=\operatorname{diam}(\Omega). In addition to ΔjsubscriptΔ𝑗\Delta_{j}, the accuracy is affected by the resolution of the partition, which is the maximum diameter of the cells, denoted by

δ≔maxθ∈{0,1}r⁡diam⁡(Ωθ).≔𝛿subscript𝜃superscript01𝑟diamsubscriptΩ𝜃\delta\coloneqq\max_{\theta\in\{0,1\}^{r}}\operatorname{diam}(\Omega_{\theta}).
Theorem 4.2 (Accuracy of Algorithm 4).

Algorithm 4 that transforms true data 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} into synthetic data 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} has the following expected accuracy in the Wasserstein metric:

𝔼⁡W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒴)≤2​2n​∑j=0rσj​Δj−1+δ.𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇𝒴22𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑟subscript𝜎𝑗subscriptΔ𝑗1𝛿\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}\right)\leq\frac{2\sqrt{2}}{n}\sum_{j=0}^{r}\sigma_{j}\Delta_{j-1}+\delta.

Here μ𝒳subscript𝜇𝒳\mu_{\mathcal{X}} and μ𝒴subscript𝜇𝒴\mu_{\mathcal{Y}} are the empirical probability distributions on the true and synthetic data, respectively.

The privacy and accuracy guarantees of Algorithm 4 (Theorems 4.1 and 4.2) hold for any choice of noise levels σjsubscript𝜎𝑗\sigma_{j}. By optimizing σjsubscript𝜎𝑗\sigma_{j}, we can achieve the best accuracy for a given level of privacy.

Theorem 4.3 (Optimized accuracy).

With the optimal choice of magnitude levels (A.4), Algorithm 4 that transforms true data 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} into synthetic data 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} is ε𝜀\varepsilon-differential private, and has the following expected accuracy in the 111-Wasserstein distance:

𝔼⁡W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒴)≤2ε​n​(∑j=0rΔj−1)2+δ.𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇𝒴2𝜀𝑛superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑟subscriptΔ𝑗12𝛿\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}\right)\leq\frac{\sqrt{2}}{\varepsilon n}\Big{(}\sum_{j=0}^{r}\sqrt{\Delta_{j-1}}\Big{)}^{2}+\delta.

Here μ𝒳subscript𝜇𝒳\mu_{\mathcal{X}} and μ𝒴subscript𝜇𝒴\mu_{\mathcal{Y}} are the empirical measures of the true and synthetic data, respectively.

Corollary 4.4 (Optimized accuracy for hypercubes).

When Ω=[0,1]dΩsuperscript01𝑑\Omega=[0,1]^{d} equipped with the ℓ∞superscriptℓ\ell^{\infty} metric, with the optimal choice of magnitude levels (A.4) and the optimal choice of

r={log2⁡(ε​n)−1 if ​d=1,log2⁡(ε​n) if ​d≥2,r=\left\{\begin{aligned} &\log_{2}(\varepsilon n)-1&\textrm{ if }d=1,\\ &\log_{2}(\varepsilon n)&\textrm{ if }d\geq 2,\end{aligned}\right.

we have

𝔼W1(μ𝒳,μ𝒴)≲{log2⁡(ε​n)ε​n, if ​d=1,(ε​n)−1/d, if ​d≥2.\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}})\lesssim\left\{\begin{aligned} \frac{\log^{2}(\varepsilon n)}{\varepsilon n},\quad\textrm{ if }d=1,\\ (\varepsilon n)^{-1/d},\quad\textrm{ if }d\geq 2.\end{aligned}\right.
Remark 4.5 (Computational efficiency of Algorithm 4).

Since a binary hierarchical partition has 2rsuperscript2𝑟2^{r} cells in total, the running time of Algorithm 4 is O​(2r)𝑂superscript2𝑟O(2^{r}). When Ω=[0,1]dΩsuperscript01𝑑\Omega=[0,1]^{d}, with the same optimal choice of r𝑟r in Corollary 4.4, the running time of PMM becomes O​(ε​d​n)𝑂𝜀𝑑𝑛O(\varepsilon dn).

4.5. Proof of Theorem 4.2

For the proof of Theorem 4.2, we introduce a quantitative notion for the incomparability of two vectors on the plane. For vectors a,b∈ℤ+2𝑎𝑏superscriptsubscriptℤ2a,b\in\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}, we define

flux(a,b):={0if a and b are comparable,min⁡(|a1−b1|,|a2−b2|)otherwise.\operatorname{flux}(a,b)\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\begin{cases}0&\text{if $a$ and $b$ are comparable,}\\ \min\left(\,\mathinner{\!\left\lvert a_{1}-b_{1}\right\rvert},\,\mathinner{\!\left\lvert a_{2}-b_{2}\right\rvert}\right)&\text{otherwise}.\end{cases}
Lemma 4.6 (Flux as incomparability).

flux⁡(a,b)flux𝑎𝑏\operatorname{flux}(a,b) is the ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}-distance from a𝑎a to the set of points that are comparable to b𝑏b.

For example, if a=(1,9)𝑎19a=(1,9) and b=(6,7)𝑏67b=(6,7), then flux⁡(a,b)=2flux𝑎𝑏2\operatorname{flux}(a,b)=2. Note that a𝑎a has a distance 222 to the vector (1,7)17(1,7) which is comparable with b𝑏b.

Lemma 4.7 (Flux as transfer).

Suppose we have two bins with a1subscript𝑎1a_{1} and a2subscript𝑎2a_{2} balls in them. Then one can achieve b1subscript𝑏1b_{1} and b2subscript𝑏2b_{2} balls in these bins by:

  1. (a)

    first making the total number of balls correct by adding a total of (b1+b2)−(a1−a2)subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2(b_{1}+b_{2})-(a_{1}-a_{2}) balls to the two bins (or removing, if that number is negative);

  2. (b)

    then transferring flux⁡((a1,a2),(b1,b2))fluxsubscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2\operatorname{flux}\left((a_{1},a_{2}),\,(b_{1},b_{2})\right) balls from one bin to the other.

For example, suppose that one bin has 111 ball and the other has 999. Then we can achieve 666 and 777 balls in these bins by first adding 333 balls to the first bin and transferring 222 balls from the second to the first bin. As we noted above, 222 is the flux between the vectors (1,9)19(1,9) and b=(6,7)𝑏67b=(6,7).

Lemma 4.7 can be generalized to the hierarchical binary partition of ΩΩ\Omega as follows.

Lemma 4.8.

Consider any data set 𝒳∈Ωn𝒳superscriptΩ𝑛\mathcal{X}\in\Omega^{n}, and let (nθ)θ∈{0,1}rsubscriptsubscript𝑛𝜃𝜃superscript01𝑟(n_{\theta})_{\theta\in\{0,1\}^{r}} be its counts. Consider any consistent vector of non-negative integers (mθ)θ∈{0,1}rsubscriptsubscript𝑚𝜃𝜃superscript01𝑟(m_{\theta})_{\theta\in\{0,1\}^{r}}. Then one can transform 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} into a set 𝒵∈Ωm𝒵superscriptΩ𝑚\mathcal{Z}\in\Omega^{m} that has counts (mθ)θ∈{0,1}rsubscriptsubscript𝑚𝜃𝜃superscript01𝑟(m_{\theta})_{\theta\in\{0,1\}^{r}} by:

  1. (a)

    first making the total number of points correct by adding a total of m−n𝑚𝑛m-n points to ΩΩ\Omega (or remove, if that number is negative);

  2. (b)

    then transferring flux⁡((nθ​0,nθ​1),(mθ​0,mθ​1))fluxsubscript𝑛𝜃0subscript𝑛𝜃1subscript𝑚𝜃0subscript𝑚𝜃1\operatorname{flux}\left((n_{\theta 0},n_{\theta 1}),\,(m_{\theta 0},m_{\theta 1})\right) points from Ωθ​0subscriptΩ𝜃0\Omega_{\theta 0} to Ωθ​1subscriptΩ𝜃1\Omega_{\theta 1} or vice versa, for all j=0,…,r−1𝑗0…𝑟1j=0,\ldots,r-1 and θ∈{0,1}j𝜃superscript01𝑗\theta\in\{0,1\}^{j}.

Combining the concept of the fluxflux\operatorname{flux} and our algorithm, the following two lemmas are useful in the proof of Theorem 4.2.

Lemma 4.9.

In Algorithm 4, we have

flux⁡((nθ​0,nθ​1),(mθ​0,mθ​1))≤max⁡(|λθ​0|,|λθ​1|)fluxsubscript𝑛𝜃0subscript𝑛𝜃1subscript𝑚𝜃0subscript𝑚𝜃1subscript𝜆𝜃0subscript𝜆𝜃1\operatorname{flux}\left((n_{\theta 0},n_{\theta 1}),\,(m_{\theta 0},m_{\theta 1})\right)\leq\max\left(\,\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{\theta 0}\right\rvert},\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{\theta 1}\right\rvert}\right)

for all j=0,…,r−1𝑗0…𝑟1j=0,\ldots,r-1 and θ∈{0,1}j𝜃superscript01𝑗\theta\in\{0,1\}^{j}.

Lemma 4.10.

For any finite multisets U⊂V𝑈𝑉U\subset V such that all elements in U𝑈U are from ΩΩ\Omega, one has

W1​(μU,μV)≤|V∖U||V|⋅diam⁡(Ω).subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝑈subscript𝜇𝑉⋅𝑉𝑈𝑉diamΩW_{1}(\mu_{U},\mu_{V})\leq\frac{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert V\setminus U\right\rvert}}{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert V\right\rvert}}\cdot\operatorname{diam}(\Omega).
Proof.

(Proof of Theorem 4.2) Owing to Lemma 4.8 and Lemma 4.9, the creation of synthetic data from the true data 𝒳↦𝒴maps-to𝒳𝒴\mathcal{X}\mapsto\mathcal{Y}, described by Algorithm 4, can be achieved by the following three steps.

  1. 1.

    Transform the n𝑛n-point input set 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} to an m𝑚m-point set 𝒳1subscript𝒳1\mathcal{X}_{1} by adding or removing |m−n|𝑚𝑛\mathinner{\!\left\lvert m-n\right\rvert} points.

  2. 2.

    Transform 𝒳1subscript𝒳1\mathcal{X}_{1} to 𝒳2subscript𝒳2\mathcal{X}_{2} by moving at most max⁡(|λθ​0|,|λθ​1|)subscript𝜆𝜃0subscript𝜆𝜃1\max\left(\,\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{\theta 0}\right\rvert},\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{\theta 1}\right\rvert}\right) many data points for each j=0,1,…,r−1𝑗01…𝑟1j=0,1,\dots,r-1 and θ∈{0,1}j𝜃superscript01𝑗\theta\in\{0,1\}^{j} between the two parts of the region ΩθsubscriptΩ𝜃\Omega_{\theta}.

  3. 3.

    Transforms 𝒳2subscript𝒳2\mathcal{X}_{2} to the output data 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} by relocating points within their cells.

We will analyze the accuracy of these steps one at a time.

Analyzing Step 2. The total distance the points are moved at this step is bounded by

∑j=0r−1∑θ∈{0,1}jmax⁡(|λθ​0|,|λθ​1|)​diam⁡(Ωθ)≕D.≕superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑟1subscript𝜃superscript01𝑗subscript𝜆𝜃0subscript𝜆𝜃1diamsubscriptΩ𝜃𝐷\sum_{j=0}^{r-1}\sum_{\theta\in\{0,1\}^{j}}\max\left(\,\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{\theta 0}\right\rvert},\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{\theta 1}\right\rvert}\right)\operatorname{diam}(\Omega_{\theta})\eqqcolon D. (4.2)

Since |𝒳1|=msubscript𝒳1𝑚\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{X}_{1}\right\rvert}=m, it follows that

W1​(μ𝒳1,μ𝒳2)≤Dm.subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇subscript𝒳1subscript𝜇subscript𝒳2𝐷𝑚W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}_{1}},\mu_{\mathcal{X}_{2}})\leq\frac{D}{m}. (4.3)

Combining Steps 1 and 2. Recall that step 1 transforms the input data 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} with |𝒳|=n𝒳𝑛\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{X}\right\rvert}=n into 𝒳1subscript𝒳1\mathcal{X}_{1} with |𝒳1|=m=n+sign⁡(λ)⋅⌊|λ|⌋subscript𝒳1𝑚𝑛⋅sign𝜆𝜆\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{X}_{1}\right\rvert}=m=n+\operatorname{sign}(\lambda)\cdot\lfloor|\lambda|\rfloor by adding or removing points, depending on the sign of λ𝜆\lambda.

Case 1: λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0. Here 𝒳1subscript𝒳1\mathcal{X}_{1} is obtained from 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} by adding ⌊λ⌋𝜆\lfloor\lambda\rfloor points, so Lemma 4.10 gives

W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒳1)≤λm⋅Δ0.subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇subscript𝒳1⋅𝜆𝑚subscriptΔ0W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{X}_{1}})\leq\frac{\lambda}{m}\cdot\Delta_{0}.

Combining this with (4.3) by triangle inequality, we conclude that

W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒳2)≤λ​Δ0+Dm≤λ​Δ0+Dn.subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇subscript𝒳2𝜆subscriptΔ0𝐷𝑚𝜆subscriptΔ0𝐷𝑛W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{X}_{2}})\leq\frac{\lambda\Delta_{0}+D}{m}\leq\frac{\lambda\Delta_{0}+D}{n}.

Case 2: λ<0𝜆0\lambda<0. Here 𝒳1subscript𝒳1\mathcal{X}_{1} is obtained from 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} by removing a set 𝒳0subscript𝒳0\mathcal{X}_{0} of n−m=⌊|λ|⌋𝑛𝑚𝜆n-m=\lfloor\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda\right\rvert}\rfloor points. Furthermore, by our analysis of step 2, 𝒳2subscript𝒳2\mathcal{X}_{2} is obtained from 𝒳1subscript𝒳1\mathcal{X}_{1} by moving points the total distance at most D𝐷D. Therefore, 𝒳2∪𝒳0subscript𝒳2subscript𝒳0\mathcal{X}_{2}\cup\mathcal{X}_{0} (as a multiset) is obtained from 𝒳=𝒳1∪𝒳0𝒳subscript𝒳1subscript𝒳0\mathcal{X}=\mathcal{X}_{1}\cup\mathcal{X}_{0} by moving points the total distance at most D𝐷D, too. (The points in 𝒳0subscript𝒳0\mathcal{X}_{0} remain unmoved.) Since |𝒳|=n𝒳𝑛\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{X}\right\rvert}=n, it follows that

W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒳2∪𝒳0)≤Dn.subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇subscript𝒳2subscript𝒳0𝐷𝑛W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{X}_{2}\cup\mathcal{X}_{0}})\leq\frac{D}{n}.

Moreover, Lemma 4.10 gives

W1​(μ𝒳2,μ𝒳2∪𝒳0)≤|𝒳0||𝒳2∪𝒳0|⋅diam⁡(Ω)≤|λ|​Δ0n.subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇subscript𝒳2subscript𝜇subscript𝒳2subscript𝒳0⋅subscript𝒳0subscript𝒳2subscript𝒳0diamΩ𝜆subscriptΔ0𝑛W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}_{2}},\mu_{\mathcal{X}_{2}\cup\mathcal{X}_{0}})\leq\frac{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{X}_{0}\right\rvert}}{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mathcal{X}_{2}\cup\mathcal{X}_{0}\right\rvert}}\cdot\operatorname{diam}(\Omega)\leq\frac{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda\right\rvert}\Delta_{0}}{n}.

(Here we used that the multiset 𝒳2∪𝒳0subscript𝒳2subscript𝒳0\mathcal{X}_{2}\cup\mathcal{X}_{0} has the same number of points as 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, which is n𝑛n.) Combining the two bounds by triangle inequality, we obtain

W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒳2)≤|λ|​Δ0+Dn.subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇subscript𝒳2𝜆subscriptΔ0𝐷𝑛W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{X}_{2}})\leq\frac{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda\right\rvert}\Delta_{0}+D}{n}. (4.4)

In other words, this bound holds in both cases.

Analyzing Step 3. This step is the easiest to analyze: since 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} is obtained from 𝒳2subscript𝒳2\mathcal{X}_{2} by relocating the points are relocated within their cells, and the maximal diameter of the cells is δ𝛿\delta, we have W1​(μ𝒳2,μ𝒴)≤δ.subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇subscript𝒳2subscript𝜇𝒴𝛿W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}_{2}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}})\leq\delta. Combining this with (4.4) by triangle inequality, we conclude that

W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒴)≤|λ|​Δ0+Dn+δ.subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇𝒴𝜆subscriptΔ0𝐷𝑛𝛿W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}})\leq\frac{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda\right\rvert}\Delta_{0}+D}{n}+\delta.

Taking expectation. Recall the definition of D𝐷D from (4.2). We get

𝔼⁡W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒴)≤1n​[𝔼⁡[|λ|]​Δ0+∑j=0r−1∑θ∈{0,1}j𝔼⁡[max⁡(|λθ​0|,|λθ​1|)]​diam⁡(Ωθ)]+δ.𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇𝒴1𝑛delimited-[]𝔼𝜆subscriptΔ0superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑟1subscript𝜃superscript01𝑗𝔼subscript𝜆𝜃0subscript𝜆𝜃1diamsubscriptΩ𝜃𝛿\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}})\leq\frac{1}{n}\left[\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\,\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda\right\rvert}\right]\Delta_{0}+\sum_{j=0}^{r-1}\sum_{\theta\in\{0,1\}^{j}}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\max\left(\,\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{\theta 0}\right\rvert},\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{\theta 1}\right\rvert}\right)\right]\operatorname{diam}(\Omega_{\theta})\right]+\delta.

Since λ∼Lapℤ⁡(σ0)similar-to𝜆subscriptLapℤsubscript𝜎0\lambda\sim\operatorname{Lap}_{\mathbb{Z}}(\sigma_{0}), by (B.1) we have 𝔼[|λ|]≤(𝔼(λ)2)1/2≤2σ0.\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\,\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda\right\rvert}\right]\leq(\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\lambda)^{2})^{1/2}\leq\sqrt{2}\sigma_{0}. Similarly, since λθ​0subscript𝜆𝜃0\lambda_{\theta 0} and λθ​1subscript𝜆𝜃1\lambda_{\theta 1} are independent Lapℤ⁡(σj+1)subscriptLapℤsubscript𝜎𝑗1\operatorname{Lap}_{\mathbb{Z}}(\sigma_{j+1}) random variables, 𝔼⁡[max⁡(|λθ​0|,|λθ​1|)]≤2​2​σj+1𝔼subscript𝜆𝜃0subscript𝜆𝜃122subscript𝜎𝑗1\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\max\left(\,\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{\theta 0}\right\rvert},\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{\theta 1}\right\rvert}\right)\right]\leq 2\sqrt{2}\sigma_{j+1}. Substituting these estimates and rearranging the terms of the sum will complete the proof. ∎

Appendix A Additional proofs

A.1. Proof of Proposition 3.2

We will apply the chaining argument (see, e.g., [45, Chapter 8]) to deduce a bound similar to Dudley’s inequality.

Step 1: (Finding nets)

A.2. Proof of Corollary 3.3

Proof.

For Ω=[0,1]dΩsuperscript01𝑑\Omega=[0,1]^{d} with l∞subscript𝑙l_{\infty}-norm, we have diam⁡(Ω)=1diamΩ1\operatorname{diam}(\Omega)=1 and the covering number

𝒩([0,1]d,u,∥⋅∥∞)≤u−d.\mathcal{N}([0,1]^{d},u,\|\cdot\|_{\infty})\leq u^{-d}.

Then, as the domain Ω=[0,1]dΩsuperscript01𝑑\Omega=[0,1]^{d} is connected and centered, we can apply the bound for the covering number of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} from [48, Theorem 17]:

𝒩(ℱ,u,∥⋅∥∞)≤(2⌈2/u⌉+1)2𝒩([0,1]d,u/2,∥⋅∥∞),\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{F},u,\|\cdot\|_{\infty})\leq\left(2\left\lceil{2}/u\right\rceil+1\right)2^{\mathcal{N}\left([0,1]^{d},u/2,\|\cdot\|_{\infty}\right)},
⟹log𝒩(ℱ,u,∥⋅∥∞)≲𝒩(Ω,u/2,∥⋅∥∞)≲(u/2)−d.\Longrightarrow\log\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{F},u,\|\cdot\|_{\infty})\lesssim\mathcal{N}(\Omega,{u}/{2},\|\cdot\|_{\infty})\lesssim(u/2)^{-d}.

Applying the inequality above to (A.1), we get

Ln≤C​(2​α+1n​∫α∞(u/2)−d/2​du+1n​∫α∞(u/2)−d​du).subscript𝐿𝑛𝐶2𝛼1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝛼superscript𝑢2𝑑2differential-d𝑢1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝛼superscript𝑢2𝑑differential-d𝑢L_{n}\leq C\left(2\alpha+\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\int_{\alpha}^{\infty}(u/2)^{-d/2}\mathrm{d}u+\frac{1}{{n}}\int_{\alpha}^{\infty}(u/2)^{-d}\mathrm{d}u\right). (A.2)

Compute the integral for the case d=2𝑑2d=2 and d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3,

Ln(f)≤{C​(2​α+2n​log⁡2α+2n​(α2)−1) if ​d=2.C​(2​α+2n⋅1d2−1​(α2)1−d2+2n⋅1d−1​(α2)1−d) if ​d≥3.L_{n}(f)\leq\left\{\begin{aligned} &C\Bigg{(}2\alpha+\frac{2}{\sqrt{n}}\log\frac{2}{\alpha}+\frac{2}{n}\left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right)^{-1}\Bigg{)}&\quad\textrm{ if }d=2.\\ &C\Bigg{(}2\alpha+\frac{2}{\sqrt{n}}\cdot\frac{1}{\frac{d}{2}-1}\left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right)^{1-\frac{d}{2}}+\frac{2}{n}\cdot\frac{1}{d-1}\left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\right)^{1-d}\Bigg{)}\quad&\textrm{ if }d\geq 3.\end{aligned}\right.

Choosing α=2​n−1/d𝛼2superscript𝑛1𝑑\alpha=2n^{-1/d} finishes the cases for d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2.

When d=1𝑑1d=1, the Dudley integral in (A.2) is divergent. However, note that diam⁡(ℱ)≤2diamℱ2\operatorname{diam}(\mathcal{F})\leq 2 and hence log𝒩(ℱ,u,∥⋅∥∞)=0\log\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{F},u,\|\cdot\|_{\infty})=0 for u>1𝑢1u>1. From (A.1), we have

Ln​(ℱ)subscript𝐿𝑛ℱ\displaystyle L_{n}(\mathcal{F}) ≤C​(2​α+1n​∫α1(u/2)−1/2​du+1n​∫α1(u/2)−1​du)absent𝐶2𝛼1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝛼1superscript𝑢212differential-d𝑢1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝛼1superscript𝑢21differential-d𝑢\displaystyle\leq C\left(2\alpha+\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\int_{\alpha}^{1}(u/2)^{-1/2}\mathrm{d}u+\frac{1}{{n}}\int_{\alpha}^{1}(u/2)^{-1}\mathrm{d}u\right)
≤C​(2​α+2​(2−α)n+2n​log⁡1α).absent𝐶2𝛼22𝛼𝑛2𝑛1𝛼\displaystyle\leq C\left(2\alpha+\frac{2(\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{\alpha})}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{2}{n}\log\frac{1}{\alpha}\right).

The optimal choice of α𝛼\alpha is α∼n−1/2similar-to𝛼superscript𝑛12\alpha\sim n^{-1/2}, which gives us the result for d=1𝑑1d=1. ∎

A.3. Proof of Proposition 3.4

Proof.

Then

ℙ​{ν1=η​}ℙ​{ν2=η​}ℙsubscript𝜈1𝜂ℙsubscript𝜈2𝜂\displaystyle\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{\nu_{1}=\eta\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{\nu_{2}=\eta\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}} =∏i=1mℙ​{λi=n​(η−μ𝒴1¯)i​}ℙ​{λi=n​(η−μ𝒴2¯)i​}=∏i=1mexp⁡(−ε​n​|(η−μ𝒴1¯)i|)exp⁡(−ε​n​|(η−μ𝒴2¯)i|)absentsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑚ℙsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑛subscript𝜂¯subscript𝜇subscript𝒴1𝑖ℙsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑛subscript𝜂¯subscript𝜇subscript𝒴2𝑖superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑚𝜀𝑛subscript𝜂¯subscript𝜇subscript𝒴1𝑖𝜀𝑛subscript𝜂¯subscript𝜇subscript𝒴2𝑖\displaystyle=\prod_{i=1}^{m}\frac{\mathbb{P}\left\{\lambda_{i}=n(\eta-\overline{\mu_{\mathcal{Y}_{1}}})_{i}\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}{\mathbb{P}\left\{\lambda_{i}=n(\eta-\overline{\mu_{\mathcal{Y}_{2}}})_{i}\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}}=\prod_{i=1}^{m}\frac{\exp(-\varepsilon n|(\eta-\overline{\mu_{\mathcal{Y}_{1}}})_{i}|)}{\exp(-\varepsilon n|(\eta-\overline{\mu_{\mathcal{Y}_{2}}})_{i}|)}
≤exp⁡(ε​n​‖μ𝒴2−μ𝒴1‖1)≤eε.absent𝜀𝑛subscriptnormsubscript𝜇subscript𝒴2subscript𝜇subscript𝒴11superscript𝑒𝜀\displaystyle\leq\exp\left(\varepsilon n\|{\mu_{\mathcal{Y}_{2}}}-{\mu_{\mathcal{Y}_{1}}}\|_{1}\right)\leq e^{\varepsilon}.

A.4. Proof of Proposition 3.5

Proof.

After a change of variable fi′=fi+1superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖′subscript𝑓𝑖1f_{i}^{\prime}=f_{i}+1, we can rewrite it as

Next, we can consider the dual problem of the linear programming problem above. The duality theory in linear programming [44, Chapter 12] showed that the original problem and the dual problem have the same optimal solution. Let ui​j,ui​j′≥0subscript𝑢𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑗′0u_{ij},u_{ij}^{\prime}\geq 0 be the dual variable for the linear constraints about fi′−fj′superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑗′f_{i}^{\prime}-f_{j}^{\prime} and −fi′+fj′superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑗′-f_{i}^{\prime}+f_{j}^{\prime}, and let vi≥0subscript𝑣𝑖0v_{i}\geq 0 be the dual variable for the equation fi′≤2superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖′2f_{i}^{\prime}\leq 2. As the linear programming above is in the standard form, by the duality theory, it is equivalent to

To find the minimizer τ𝜏\tau for a given ν𝜈\nu, we regard τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i} as variables and add the constraints of τ𝜏\tau being a probability measure. Also, we can eliminate the constant ν​(Ω)−1𝜈Ω1\nu(\Omega)-1 in the target function. So we get the linear programming problem:

There are 2​m22superscript𝑚22m^{2} variables in total and m+1𝑚1m+1 linear constraints, and the minimizer (τi)i=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜏𝑖𝑖1𝑚(\tau_{i})_{i=1}^{m} is what we want. ∎

A.5. Proof of Theorem 3.6

Proof.

We transformed the original data measure μ𝒳subscript𝜇𝒳\mu_{\mathcal{X}} with three steps: μ𝒳⟶μ𝒴⟶ν⟶ν^.⟶subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇𝒴⟶𝜈⟶^𝜈\mu_{\mathcal{X}}\longrightarrow\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}\longrightarrow\nu\longrightarrow\hat{\nu}.

=𝔼​sup‖f‖Lip≤1|∑i=1mf​(yi)​(nin+λin−nin)|=mε​n​L~m​(ℱ).absent𝔼subscriptsupremumsubscriptnorm𝑓Lip1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚𝑓subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛subscript𝜆𝑖𝑛subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛𝑚𝜀𝑛subscript~𝐿𝑚ℱ\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\sup_{\|f\|_{\mathrm{Lip}}\leq 1}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{m}f(y_{i})\left(\frac{n_{i}}{n}+\frac{\lambda_{i}}{n}-\frac{n_{i}}{n}\right)\right|=\frac{m}{\varepsilon n}\widetilde{L}_{m}(\mathcal{F}). (A.3)

Step 3: For the last step, we have dBL​(ν,ν^)≤dBL​(μ𝒴,ν)subscript𝑑BL𝜈^𝜈subscript𝑑BLsubscript𝜇𝒴𝜈d_{\mathrm{BL}}(\nu,\hat{\nu})\leq d_{\mathrm{BL}}(\mu_{\mathcal{Y}},\nu) because ν^^𝜈\hat{\nu} is the closest probability measure to ν𝜈\nu from Proposition 3.5. As a result, we have

W1​(μ,ν^)=dBL​(μ,ν^)subscript𝑊1𝜇^𝜈subscript𝑑BL𝜇^𝜈\displaystyle W_{1}(\mu,\hat{\nu})=d_{\mathrm{BL}}(\mu,\hat{\nu}) ≤dBL​(μ𝒳,μ𝒴)+dBL​(μ𝒴,ν)+dBL​(ν,ν^)absentsubscript𝑑BLsubscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇𝒴subscript𝑑BLsubscript𝜇𝒴𝜈subscript𝑑BL𝜈^𝜈\displaystyle\leq d_{\mathrm{BL}}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}})+d_{\mathrm{BL}}(\mu_{\mathcal{Y}},\nu)+d_{\mathrm{BL}}(\nu,\hat{\nu})

After taking the expectation, we can apply (A.3) to get the desired inequality. ∎

A.6. Proof of Corollary 3.7

Proof.

Using Theorem 3.6, we have

𝔼⁡W1​(μ𝒳,ν^)≤maxi⁡diam⁡(Ωi)+2​mε​n​L~m​(ℱ).𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳^𝜈subscript𝑖diamsubscriptΩ𝑖2𝑚𝜀𝑛subscript~𝐿𝑚ℱ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\hat{\nu})\leq\max_{i}\operatorname{diam}(\Omega_{i})+\frac{2m}{\varepsilon n}\widetilde{L}_{m}(\mathcal{F}).

By assumption we have maxi⁡diam⁡(Ωi)≍m−1/d≍(ε​n)−1/dasymptotically-equalssubscript𝑖diamsubscriptΩ𝑖superscript𝑚1𝑑asymptotically-equalssuperscript𝜀𝑛1𝑑\max_{i}\operatorname{diam}(\Omega_{i})\asymp m^{-1/d}\asymp(\varepsilon n)^{-1/d}. And by 3.3 we have the bound for the Laplacian complexity

L~m(ℱ)≤{C​(ε​n)−1/2 if ​d=1,C​log⁡n⋅(ε​n)−1/2 if ​d=2,C​(ε​n)−1/d if ​d≥3.\widetilde{L}_{m}(\mathcal{F})\leq\left\{\begin{aligned} &C(\varepsilon n)^{-1/2}\quad&\textrm{ if }d=1,\\ &{C\log n}\cdot(\varepsilon n)^{-1/2}\quad&\textrm{ if }d=2,\\ &{C}{(\varepsilon n)^{-{1}/{d}}}\quad&\textrm{ if }d\geq 3.\end{aligned}\right.

When d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3, the two terms are comparable. And when d=1,2𝑑12d=1,2, the Laplacian complexity dominates the error. Combining the two inequalities gives the result. ∎

A.7. Proof of Theorem 4.1

Theorem 4.1 can be obtained by applying the parallel composition lemma [24]. Here we present a self-contained proof by considering an inhomogeneous version of the classical Laplacian mechanism [24].

Lemma A.1 (Inhomogeneous Laplace mechanism).

Let F:Ωn→ℝk:𝐹superscriptΩ𝑛→superscriptℝ𝑘F\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\Omega^{n}\to\mathbb{R}^{k} be any map, s=(si)i=1k∈ℝ+k𝑠superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑖1𝑘superscriptsubscriptℝ𝑘s=(s_{i})_{i=1}^{k}\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{k} be a fixed vector, and λ=(λi)i=1k𝜆superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑖1𝑘\lambda=(\lambda_{i})_{i=1}^{k} be a random vector with independent coordinates λi∼Lapℤ⁡(si)similar-tosubscript𝜆𝑖subscriptLapℤsubscript𝑠𝑖\lambda_{i}\sim\operatorname{Lap}_{\mathbb{Z}}(s_{i}). Proof of Theorem 4.1.

Consider the map F​(𝒳)=(nθ)𝐹𝒳subscript𝑛𝜃F(\mathcal{X})=(n_{\theta}) that transforms the input data into the vector of counts. ∥F​(𝒳)−F​(𝒳~)∥ℓ1​(σ)=∑j=0r1σj​∑θ∈{0,1}j|nθ−n~θ|=∑j=0r1σj=ε.subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐹𝒳𝐹~𝒳superscriptℓ1𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑟1subscript𝜎𝑗subscript𝜃superscript01𝑗subscript𝑛𝜃subscript~𝑛𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑟1subscript𝜎𝑗𝜀\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F(\mathcal{X})-F(\tilde{\mathcal{X}})\right\rVert}_{\ell^{1}(\sigma)}=\sum_{j=0}^{r}\frac{1}{\sigma_{j}}\sum_{\theta\in\{0,1\}^{j}}\mathinner{\!\left\lvert n_{\theta}-\tilde{n}_{\theta}\right\rvert}=\sum_{j=0}^{r}\frac{1}{\sigma_{j}}=\varepsilon.

A.8. Proof of Theorem 4.3

Proof.

We will use the Lagrange multipliers procedure to find the optimal choices of σjsubscript𝜎𝑗\sigma_{j}. Given the maximal layer r𝑟r, recall Theorem 4.1, we should use our privacy budget as

ε=∑j=0r1σj.𝜀superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑟1subscript𝜎𝑗\varepsilon=\sum_{j=0}^{r}\frac{1}{\sigma_{j}}.

Therefore, we aim to minimize the accuracy bound with the specified privacy budget, namely

min⁡𝔼⁡W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒴)s.t. ​ε=∑j=0r1σj.𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇𝒴s.t. 𝜀superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑟1subscript𝜎𝑗\displaystyle\min\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}})\quad\;\textrm{s.t. }\varepsilon=\sum_{j=0}^{r}\frac{1}{\sigma_{j}}.

Recall the result in Theorem 4.2. Here ε,n𝜀𝑛\varepsilon,n are given and δ𝛿\delta is fixed as long as we determine the maximal level r𝑟r. So the minimization problem is

min​∑j=0rσj​Δj−1s.t. ​ε=∑j=0r1σj.superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑟subscript𝜎𝑗subscriptΔ𝑗1s.t. 𝜀superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑟1subscript𝜎𝑗\displaystyle\min\sum_{j=0}^{r}\sigma_{j}\Delta_{j-1}\quad\;\textrm{s.t. }\varepsilon=\sum_{j=0}^{r}\frac{1}{\sigma_{j}}.

Consider the Lagrangian function

f(σ0,…,σr;t):=∑j=0rσjΔj−1−t(∑j=0r1σj−ε)f(\sigma_{0},\dots,\sigma_{r};t)\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\sum_{j=0}^{r}\sigma_{j}\Delta_{j-1}-t\left(\sum_{j=0}^{r}\frac{1}{\sigma_{j}}-\varepsilon\right)

and the corresponding equation

∂f∂σ0=⋯=∂f∂σr=∂f∂t=0.𝑓subscript𝜎0⋯𝑓subscript𝜎𝑟𝑓𝑡0\frac{\partial f}{\partial\sigma_{0}}=\dots=\frac{\partial f}{\partial\sigma_{r}}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial t}=0.

One can easily check that the equations above have a unique solution

σj=Sε​Δj−1whereS=∑j=0rΔi−1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜎𝑗𝑆𝜀subscriptΔ𝑗1where𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑟subscriptΔ𝑖1\sigma_{j}=\frac{S}{\varepsilon\sqrt{\Delta_{j-1}}}\quad\text{where}\quad S=\sum_{j=0}^{r}\sqrt{\Delta_{i-1}}. (A.4)

and it is indeed a minimal point for f​(σ0,…,σr;t)𝑓subscript𝜎0…subscript𝜎𝑟𝑡f(\sigma_{0},\dots,\sigma_{r};t).

As a result, if we fix ε𝜀\varepsilon and want Algorithm 4 to be ε𝜀\varepsilon-differentially private, we should choose the noise magnitudes as (A.4). Substituting these noise magnitudes into the accuracy Theorem 4.2, we see that the accuracy gets bounded by 2ε​n​S2+δ2𝜀𝑛superscript𝑆2𝛿\frac{\sqrt{2}}{\varepsilon n}S^{2}+\delta. ∎

A.9. Proof of Corollary 4.4

Proof.

Let Ω=[0,1]Ω01\Omega=[0,1] with the ℓ∞superscriptℓ\ell^{\infty} metric. The natural hierarchical binary decomposition of [0,1]01[0,1] (cut through the middle) makes subintervals of length diam⁡(Ωθ)=2−jdiamsubscriptΩ𝜃superscript2𝑗\operatorname{diam}(\Omega_{\theta})=2^{-j} for θ∈{0,1}j𝜃superscript01𝑗\theta\in\{0,1\}^{j}, so Δj=1subscriptΔ𝑗1\Delta_{j}=1 for all j𝑗j, and the resolution is δ=2−r𝛿superscript2𝑟\delta=2^{-r}. Theorem 4.3 makes ε𝜀\varepsilon-differential private synthetic data with accuracy

𝔼⁡W1​(μ𝒳,μ𝒴)≤2​(r+1)2ε​n+2−r.𝔼subscript𝑊1subscript𝜇𝒳subscript𝜇𝒴2superscript𝑟12𝜀𝑛superscript2𝑟\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}W_{1}\left(\mu_{\mathcal{X}},\mu_{\mathcal{Y}}\right)\leq\frac{\sqrt{2}(r+1)^{2}}{\varepsilon n}+2^{-r}.

A nearly optimal choice for r𝑟r is r=log2⁡(ε​n)−1𝑟subscript2𝜀𝑛1r=\log_{2}(\varepsilon n)-1, which yields

A.10. Proof of Lemma 4.6

Proof.

If a,b𝑎𝑏a,b are comparable, both values are zero. If a,b𝑎𝑏a,b is not comparable, we can assume a1>b1subscript𝑎1subscript𝑏1a_{1}>b_{1}, a2<b2subscript𝑎2subscript𝑏2a_{2}<b_{2} without loss of generality. The set of points that are comparable to b𝑏b is

{(x1,x2)∈ℤ+2∣x1≤b1,x2≤b2}∪{(x1,x2)∈ℤ+2∣x1≥b1,x2≥b2}.conditional-setsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2superscriptsubscriptℤ2formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥1subscript𝑏1subscript𝑥2subscript𝑏2conditional-setsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2superscriptsubscriptℤ2formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥1subscript𝑏1subscript𝑥2subscript𝑏2\{(x_{1},x_{2})\in\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}\mid x_{1}\leq b_{1},x_{2}\leq b_{2}\}\cup\{(x_{1},x_{2})\in\mathbb{Z}_{+}^{2}\mid x_{1}\geq b_{1},x_{2}\geq b_{2}\}.

Note that the distance from a𝑎a to the first set is |a1−b1|subscript𝑎1subscript𝑏1\mathinner{\!\left\lvert a_{1}-b_{1}\right\rvert} and the distance from a𝑎a to the second set is |a2−b2|subscript𝑎2subscript𝑏2\mathinner{\!\left\lvert a_{2}-b_{2}\right\rvert}. Then flux⁡(a,b)flux𝑎𝑏\operatorname{flux}(a,b) is the smaller one of the two distances, which is also the distance from a𝑎a to the union set. ∎

A.11. Proof of Lemma 4.7

Proof.

Case 1: a=(a1,a2)𝑎subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2a=(a_{1},a_{2}) and b=(b1,b2)𝑏subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2b=(b_{1},b_{2}) are comparable. Case 2: a=(a1,a2)𝑎subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2a=(a_{1},a_{2}) and b=(b1,b2)𝑏subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2b=(b_{1},b_{2}) are incomparable. Without loss of generality, we can assume that a1−b1≥0subscript𝑎1subscript𝑏10a_{1}-b_{1}\geq 0, a2−b2≤0subscript𝑎2subscript𝑏20a_{2}-b_{2}\leq 0.

Now assume that a1−b1≤b2−a2subscript𝑎1subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2subscript𝑎2a_{1}-b_{1}\leq b_{2}-a_{2}. Then flux⁡(a,b)=a1−b1≔Mflux𝑎𝑏subscript𝑎1subscript𝑏1≔𝑀\operatorname{flux}(a,b)=a_{1}-b_{1}\coloneqq M. Adding ΔΔ\Delta balls to bin 2 and transferring M𝑀M balls from bin 1 to bin 2 achieves the result. ∎

A.12. Proof of Lemma 4.8

Proof.

First, we make the total number of points in ΩΩ\Omega correct by adding m−n𝑚𝑛m-n points to ΩΩ\Omega (or removing, if that number is negative).

Apply Lemma 4.7 for the two parts of ΩΩ\Omega: bin Ω0subscriptΩ0\Omega_{0} that contains n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} points and bin Ω1subscriptΩ1\Omega_{1} that contains n1subscript𝑛1n_{1} points. Since ΩΩ\Omega already contains the correct total number of points m𝑚m, we can make the two bins contain the correct number of points, i.e. m0subscript𝑚0m_{0} and m1subscript𝑚1m_{1} respectively, by transferring flux⁡((n0,n1),(m0,m1))fluxsubscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1subscript𝑚0subscript𝑚1\operatorname{flux}\left((n_{0},n_{1}),\,(m_{0},m_{1})\right) points from one bin to the other.

Apply Lemma 4.7 for the two parts of Ω0subscriptΩ0\Omega_{0}: bin Ω00subscriptΩ00\Omega_{00} that contains n00subscript𝑛00n_{00} points and bin Ω01subscriptΩ01\Omega_{01} that contains n01subscript𝑛01n_{01} points. Since Ω0subscriptΩ0\Omega_{0} already contains the correct number of points m0subscript𝑚0m_{0}, we can make the two bins contain the correct number of points, i.e. m00subscript𝑚00m_{00} and m01subscript𝑚01m_{01} respectively, by transferring flux⁡((n00,n01),(m00,m01))fluxsubscript𝑛00subscript𝑛01subscript𝑚00subscript𝑚01\operatorname{flux}\left((n_{00},n_{01}),\,(m_{00},m_{01})\right) points from one bin to the other.

Similarly, since Ω1subscriptΩ1\Omega_{1} already has the correct number of points m1subscript𝑚1m_{1}, we can make Ω10subscriptΩ10\Omega_{10} and Ω11subscriptΩ11\Omega_{11} contain the correct number of points m10subscript𝑚10m_{10} and m11subscript𝑚11m_{11} by transferring flux⁡((n00,n01),(m00,m01))fluxsubscript𝑛00subscript𝑛01subscript𝑚00subscript𝑚01\operatorname{flux}\left((n_{00},n_{01}),\,(m_{00},m_{01})\right) points from one bin to the other.

Continuing this way, we can complete the proof. Note that the steps of the iteration procedure we described are interlocked. Each next step determines which subregion the transferred points are selected from, and which subregion they are moved to in the previous step. For example, the original step calls to add (or remove) m−n𝑚𝑛m-n points to or from ΩΩ\Omega, but does not specify how these points are distributed between the two parts Ω0subscriptΩ0\Omega_{0} and Ω1subscriptΩ1\Omega_{1}. The application of Lemma 4.7 at the next step determines this. ∎

A.13. Proof of Lemma 4.9

Proof.

We will derive this result from Lemma 4.6. ∥a−b′∥∞≤max⁡(|λθ​0|,|λθ​1|).subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑎superscript𝑏′subscript𝜆𝜃0subscript𝜆𝜃1\mathinner{\!\left\lVert a-b^{\prime}\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq\max\left(\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{\theta 0}\right\rvert},\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{\theta 1}\right\rvert}\right).

Furthermore, recall that by Algorithm 3, b′superscript𝑏′b^{\prime} is comparable to b=(mθ​0,mθ​1)𝑏subscript𝑚𝜃0subscript𝑚𝜃1b=(m_{\theta 0},m_{\theta 1}). An application of Lemma 4.6 completes the proof. ∎

A.14. Proof of Lemma 4.10

Proof.

Finding the 1-Wasserstein distance in the discrete case is equivalent to solving the optimal transformation problem. In fact, we can obtain μUsubscript𝜇𝑈\mu_{U} from μVsubscript𝜇𝑉\mu_{V} by moving |V∖U|𝑉𝑈\mathinner{\!\left\lvert V\setminus U\right\rvert} atoms of μVsubscript𝜇𝑉\mu_{V}, each having mass 1/|V|1𝑉1/\mathinner{\!\left\lvert V\right\rvert}, and distributing their mass uniformly over U𝑈U. The distance for each movement is bounded by diam⁡(Ω)diamΩ\operatorname{diam}(\Omega). Therefore the 111-Wasserstein distance between μUsubscript𝜇𝑈\mu_{U} and νVsubscript𝜈𝑉\nu_{V} is bounded by |V∖U||V|​diam⁡(Ω)𝑉𝑈𝑉diamΩ\frac{|V\setminus U|}{|V|}\operatorname{diam}(\Omega). ∎

Appendix B Discrete Laplacian distribution

Recall that the classical Laplacian distribution Lapℝ⁡(σ)subscriptLapℝ𝜎\operatorname{Lap}_{\mathbb{R}}(\sigma) is a continuous distribution with density

f​(x)=12​σ​exp⁡(−|x|/σ),x∈ℝ.formulae-sequence𝑓𝑥12𝜎𝑥𝜎𝑥ℝf(x)=\frac{1}{2\sigma}\exp\left(-\mathinner{\!\left\lvert x\right\rvert}/\sigma\right),\quad x\in\mathbb{R}.

A random variable X∼Lapℝ⁡(σ)similar-to𝑋subscriptLapℝ𝜎X\sim\operatorname{Lap}_{\mathbb{R}}(\sigma) has zero mean and

Var⁡(Z)=2​σ2.Var𝑍2superscript𝜎2\operatorname{Var}(Z)=2\sigma^{2}.

To deal with counts, it is more convenient to use the discrete Laplacian distribution Lapℤ⁡(σ)subscriptLapℤ𝜎\operatorname{Lap}_{\mathbb{Z}}(\sigma), see [30], which has probability mass function

f​(z)=1−pσ1+pσ​exp⁡(−|z|/σ),z∈ℤformulae-sequence𝑓𝑧1subscript𝑝𝜎1subscript𝑝𝜎𝑧𝜎𝑧ℤf(z)=\frac{1-p_{\sigma}}{1+p_{\sigma}}\exp\left(-\mathinner{\!\left\lvert z\right\rvert}/\sigma\right),\quad z\in\mathbb{Z}

where pσ=exp⁡(−1/σ)subscript𝑝𝜎1𝜎p_{\sigma}=\exp(-1/\sigma). A random variable Z∼Lapℤ⁡(σ)similar-to𝑍subscriptLapℤ𝜎Z\sim\operatorname{Lap}_{\mathbb{Z}}(\sigma) has zero mean and

Var⁡(Z)=2​pσ(1−pσ)2.Var𝑍2subscript𝑝𝜎superscript1subscript𝑝𝜎2\operatorname{Var}(Z)=\frac{2p_{\sigma}}{(1-p_{\sigma})^{2}}.

Thus, one can verify that discrete Laplacian has a smaller variance than its continuous counterpart:

Var⁡(Z)<2​σ2,Var𝑍2superscript𝜎2\operatorname{Var}(Z)<2\sigma^{2}, (B.1)

but the gap vanishes for large σ𝜎\sigma:

Var⁡(Z)→2​σ2as ​σ→∞.formulae-sequence→Var𝑍2superscript𝜎2→as 𝜎\operatorname{Var}(Z)\to 2\sigma^{2}\quad\text{as }\sigma\to\infty.
